com.samskivert.depot

Class KeySet<T extends PersistentRecord>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.samskivert.depot.clause.WhereClause
      • com.samskivert.depot.KeySet<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    CacheInvalidator, QueryClause, SQLFragment, ValidatingCacheInvalidator, Serializable, Iterable<Key<T>>

    public abstract class KeySet<T extends PersistentRecord>
extends WhereClause
implements Serializable, ValidatingCacheInvalidator, Iterable<Key<T>>
    Contains a set of primary keys that match a set of persistent records. This is used internally in Depot when decomposing queries into two parts: first a query for the primary keys that identify the records that match a free-form query and then another query that operates on the previously identified keys. The keys obtained in the first query are used to create a KeySet and modifications and deletions using this set will automatically flush the appropriate records from the cache.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • addClasses

        public void addClasses(Collection<Class<? extends PersistentRecord>> classSet)
        Description copied from interface: SQLFragment
        Adds all persistent classes that are brought into the SQL context by this clause: FROM clauses, JOINs, UPDATEs, anything that could create a new table abbreviation. This method should recurse into any subordinate state that may in turn bring in new classes so that sub-queries work correctly.
        Specified by:
        addClasses in interface SQLFragment

      • invalidate

        public void invalidate(PersistenceContext ctx)
        Description copied from interface: CacheInvalidator
        Must invalidate all cache entries that depend on the records being modified or deleted. This method is called just before the database statement is executed.
        Specified by:
        invalidate in interface CacheInvalidator

      • validateFlushType

        public void validateFlushType(Class<?> pClass)
        Description copied from interface: ValidatingCacheInvalidator
        Validates that this invalidator operates on the supplied persistent record class. This helps to catch programmer errors where one record type is used for a query clause and another is used for the cache invalidator.
        Specified by:
        validateFlushType in interface ValidatingCacheInvalidator

      • validateQueryType

        public void validateQueryType(Class<?> pClass)
        Description copied from class: WhereClause
        Validates that the supplied persistent record type is the type matched by this where clause. Not all clauses will be able to perform this validation, but those that can, should do so to help alleviate programmer error.
        Overrides:
        validateQueryType in class WhereClause
